services.syncthing.settings.options.maxF.description:
This option controls how many folders may concurrently be in I/O-intensive operations such as syncing or scanning.
The mechanism is described in detail in a [separate chapter](https://docs.syncthing.net/advanced/option-max-concurrency.html).

services.syncthing.settings.options.rela.description: When true, relays will be connected to and potentially used for device to device connections.

services.syncthing.settings.options.urAc.description:
Whether the user has accepted to submit anonymous usage data.
The default, 0, mean the user has not made a choice, and Syncthing will ask at some point in the future.
"-1" means no, a number above zero means that that version of usage reporting has been accepted.

services.wl-clip-persist.clipboardType.description:
The clipboard type to persist.

- `regular`: Persist the regular clipboard only (recommended).
- `primary`: Persist the primary selection only.
- `both`: Persist both regular and primary clipboards.

Note: Operating on the primary clipboard may have unintended side effects
for some applications.

services.wl-clip-persist.extraOptions.description:
Extra command-line arguments to pass to wl-clip-persist.

Available options include:
- `--write-timeout <ms>`: Timeout for writing clipboard data (default: 3000).
- `--ignore-event-on-error`: Only handle events without errors.
- `--all-mime-type-regex <regex>`: Filter events by MIME type regex.
- `--selection-size-limit <bytes>`: Limit clipboard data size.
- `--reconnect-tries <n>`: Number of reconnection attempts.
- `--reconnect-delay <ms>`: Delay between reconnect attempts (default: 100).
- `--disable-timestamps`: Disable log timestamps.

services.xcape.mapExpression.description:
The value has the grammar `Key[|OtherKey]`.

The list of key names is found in the header file
{file}`X11/keysymdef.h` (remove the
`XK_` prefix). Note that due to limitations
of X11 shifted keys must be specified as a shift key
followed by the key to be pressed rather than the actual
name of the character. For example to generate "{" the
expression `Shift_L|bracketleft` could be
used (assuming that you have a key with "{" above "[").

You can also specify keys in decimal (prefix #), octal (#0),
or hexadecimal (#0x). They will be interpreted as keycodes
unless no corresponding key name is found.

services.xcape.timeout.description:
If you hold a key longer than this timeout, xcape will not
generate a key event. Default is 500 ms.

services.xidlehook.timers.description:
A set of commands to be executed after a specific idle timeout.
The commands specified in `command` and `canceller`
are passed escaped to the script.
To use or re-use environment variables that are script-dependent, specify them
in the `environment` section.

services.xidlehook.timers.*.canceller.description:
Command executed when the user becomes active again.
This is only executed if the next timer has not been reached.
Path to executables are accepted.
The command is automatically escaped.

services.xidlehook.timers.*.command.description:
Command executed after the idle timeout is reached.
Path to executables are accepted.
The command is automatically escaped.

specialisation.description:
A set of named specialized configurations. These can be used to extend
your base configuration with additional settings. For example, you can
have specialisations named "light" and "dark"
that apply light and dark color theme configurations.

::: {.note}
This is an experimental option for now and you therefore have to
activate the specialisation by looking up and running the activation
script yourself. Running the activation script will create a new
Home Manager generation.
:::

For example, to activate the "dark" specialisation, you can
first look up your current Home Manager generation by running

```console
$ home-manager generations | head -1
2022-05-02 22:49 : id 1758 -> /nix/store/jy…ac-home-manager-generation
```

then run

```console
$ /nix/store/jy…ac-home-manager-generation/specialisation/dark/activate
Starting Home Manager activation
…
```

::: {.warning}
Since this option is experimental, the activation process may
change in backwards incompatible ways.
:::

systemd.user.automounts.description:
Definition of systemd per-user automount units. Attributes are
merged recursively.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.automount(5)`.
systemd.user.automounts.type: attribute set of (open submodule of systemd automount unit configuration)

systemd.user.automounts.<name>.Unit.Desc.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

systemd.user.automounts.<name>.Unit.Docu.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.automounts.<name>.Unit.Docu.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.enable.description: Whether to enable the user systemd service manager.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used

systemd.user.mounts.<name>.Unit.Document.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.packages.description:
Packages providing systemd user units.

This is the Home Manager equivalent of NixOS’s `systemd.packages`
option.

Files in {file}`«pkg»/share/systemd/user` will be included in the
user’s {file}`$XDG_DATA_HOME/systemd/user` directory.

systemd.user.paths.<name>.Unit.Documenta.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.paths.<name>.Unit.Documenta.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.service(5)`.

systemd.user.services.<name>.Service.Exe.description: Command that is executed when this service is started.

systemd.user.services.<name>.Unit.Descri.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

reload during Home Manager activation.

systemd.user.services.<name>.Unit.X-Rest.description:
List of free form strings that can be used to trigger a service
restart during Home Manager activation.

systemd.user.services.<name>.Unit.X-Swit.description:
The preferred method to use when switching from an old to a new
version of this service.

systemd.user.servicesStartTimeoutMs.description:
How long to wait for started services to fail until their start is
considered successful. The value 0 indicates no timeout.

systemd.user.sessionVariables.description:
Environment variables that will be set for the user session.
The variable values must be as described in
{manpage}`environment.d(5)`.
systemd.user.sessionVariables.type: attribute set of (signed integer or string)

systemd.user.settings.description:
Extra config options for user session service manager. See {manpage}`systemd-user.conf(5)` for
available options.
systemd.user.settings.type: open submodule of attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string) or a list of them for duplicate keys)

systemd.user.settings.Manager.DefaultEnv.description: Configures environment variables passed to all executed processes.
systemd.user.settings.Manager.DefaultEnv.type: attribute set of (null or string or absolute path or package)

systemd.user.settings.Manager.ManagerEnv.description: Sets environment variables just for the manager process itself.
systemd.user.settings.Manager.ManagerEnv.type: attribute set of (null or string or absolute path or package)

systemd.user.slices.description:
Definition of systemd per-user slice units. Attributes are
merged recursively.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.slice(5)`.
systemd.user.slices.type: attribute set of (open submodule of systemd slice unit configuration)

systemd.user.slices.<name>.Unit.Descript.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

systemd.user.slices.<name>.Unit.Document.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.slices.<name>.Unit.Document.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.sockets.description:
Definition of systemd per-user socket units. Attributes are
merged recursively.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.socket(5)`.
systemd.user.sockets.type: attribute set of (open submodule of systemd socket unit configuration)

systemd.user.sockets.<name>.Unit.Descrip.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

systemd.user.sockets.<name>.Unit.Documen.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.sockets.<name>.Unit.Documen.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.startServices.description:
Whether new or changed services that are wanted by active targets
should be started. Additionally, stop obsolete services from the
previous generation.

The alternatives are

`suggest` (or `false`)
: Use a very simple shell script to print suggested
  {command}`systemctl` commands to run. You will have to
  manually run those commands after the switch.

`sd-switch` (or `true`)
: Use sd-switch, a tool that determines the necessary changes and
  automatically apply them.

systemd.user.systemctlPath.description:
Absolute path to the {command}`systemctl` tool. This
option may need to be set if running Home Manager on a
non-NixOS distribution.

systemd.user.targets.description:
Definition of systemd per-user target units. Attributes are
merged recursively.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.target(5)`.
systemd.user.targets.type: attribute set of (open submodule of systemd target unit configuration)

systemd.user.targets.<name>.Unit.Descrip.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

systemd.user.targets.<name>.Unit.Documen.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.targets.<name>.Unit.Documen.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.timers.description:
Definition of systemd per-user timer units. Attributes are
merged recursively.

Note that the attributes follow the capitalization and naming used
by systemd. More details can be found in
{manpage}`systemd.timer(5)`.
systemd.user.timers.type: attribute set of (open submodule of systemd timer unit configuration)

systemd.user.timers.<name>.Unit.Descript.description: A short human-readable label of the unit.

systemd.user.timers.<name>.Unit.Document.description: List of URIs referencing documentation for the unit.
systemd.user.timers.<name>.Unit.Document.type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

systemd.user.tmpfiles.rules.description:
Rules for creating and cleaning up temporary files
automatically. See
{manpage}`tmpfiles.d(5)`
for the exact format.

targets.darwin.copyApps.directory.description: Path to link apps relative to the home directory.

targets.darwin.copyApps.enable.description: Whether to enable copying macOS applications to the user environment (works with Spotlight).

targets.darwin.copyApps.enableChecks.description: Whether to enable enable App Management checks.

targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults.description:
Set macOS user defaults. Unlike {option}`targets.darwin.defaults`,
the preferences will only be applied to the currently logged-in host. This
distinction is important for networked accounts.

Values set to `null` are ignored.

::: {.warning}
Some settings might require a re-login to take effect.
:::
targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults.type: open submodule of attribute set of attribute set of anything

targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults.\"com.description: Whether to show battery percentage in the menu bar.

targets.darwin.defaults.description:
Set macOS user defaults. Values set to `null` are
ignored.

::: {.warning}
Some settings might require a re-login to take effect.
:::

::: {.warning}
Some settings are only read from
{option}`targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults`.
:::
targets.darwin.defaults.type: open submodule of attribute set of attribute set of anything

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.apple.Safa.description:
Configures the web inspector.

::: {.warning}
Instead of setting this option directly, set
{option}`IncludeDevelopMenu` instead.
:::
Whether to enable autofill of credit card numbers.
Whether to enable autofill of usernames and passwords.
Whether to enable opening of downloaded files.
Whether to enable "Develop" menu in the menu bar.

Configures the web inspector.

::: {.warning}
Instead of setting this option directly, set
{option}`IncludeDevelopMenu` instead.
:::

Show the "Develop" menu in Safari's menubar.

::: {.warning}
Instead of setting this option directly, set
{option}`"com.apple.Safari".IncludeDevelopMenu` instead.
:::

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.apple.desk.description:
Disable use of {file}`.DS_Store` files on network shares.
See [the
official article](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208209) for more info.
Disable use of {file}`.DS_Store` files on thumb drives.

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.apple.dock.description: Whether to enable grouping of windows by application in Mission Control.
Position of the Dock on the screen
Whether to enable locking of the dock size.
Sets the size of the dock.

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.apple.find.description: Automatically delete items from trash after 30 days
Show the path bar at the bottom of a Finder window
Show the status bar at the bottom of a Finder window

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.apple.menu.description:
This option no longer works on macOS 11 and later. Instead, use
{option}`targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults.\"com.apple.controlcenter\".BatteryShowPercentage`.

Whether to show battery percentage in the menu bar.
Whether to enable showing an analog clock instead of a digital one.
Whether to enable showing a 24-hour clock, instead of a 12-hour clock.
Show the AM/PM label. Useful if Show24Hour is false. Default is null.

Show the full date. Default is null.

0 = When Space Allows
1 = Always
2 = Never
Whether to enable showing the day of the month.
Whether to enable showing the day of the week.
Whether to enable showing the clock with second precision, instead of minutes.

targets.darwin.defaults.\"com.googlecode.description: Whether to enable placement of new tabs at the end of the tab bar.
Whether to enable arrow keys when scrolling in alternate screen mode.
Whether to enable copy to clipboard upon selecting text.
Whether to enable experimental key handling for AquaSKK compatibility.

Configures how to restore tmux windows when attaching to a session.

**Possible Values**

`0`
: Native windows

`1`
: Native tabs in a new window

`2`
: Tabs in the attaching window

targets.darwin.defaults.NSGlobalDomain.A.description: Sets the language to use in the preferred order.
Whether to enable the metric system.
Repeat a key when it is held down (false) or display the accented character selector (true)
Always show file extensions in Finder

targets.darwin.defaults.NSGlobalDomain.K.description:
Interval between key repetitions when holding down a key. Lower is
faster. When setting through the control panel, 2 is the lowest value,
and 120 the highest.

targets.darwin.defaults.NSGlobalDomain.N.description: Whether to enable period with double space.

targets.darwin.keybindings.description:
This will configure the default keybindings for text fields in macOS
applications. See
[Apple's documentation](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/EventOverview/TextDefaultsBindings/TextDefaultsBindings.html)
for more details.

::: {.warning}
Existing keybinding configuration will be wiped when using this
option.
:::

targets.darwin.linkApps.directory.description: Path to link apps relative to the home directory.

targets.darwin.linkApps.enable.description: Whether to enable linking macOS applications to the user environment.

targets.genericLinux.enable.description:
Whether to enable settings that make Home Manager work better on
GNU/Linux distributions other than NixOS.

targets.genericLinux.gpu.enable.description: Whether to enable GPU driver integration for non-NixOS systems.

targets.genericLinux.gpu.nixStateDirecto.description:
The path to the Nix state directory. This only needs to be changed
from default if the path was overridden, e.g., by setting the
`NIX_STATE_DIR` environment variable.

targets.genericLinux.gpu.nvidia.enable.description: Whether to enable proprietary Nvidia drivers.

targets.genericLinux.gpu.nvidia.sha256.description:
The hash of the downloaded driver file. It can be obtained by
running, for example,

```sh
nix store prefetch-file https://download.nvidia.com/XFree86/Linux-x86_64/@VERSION@/NVIDIA-Linux-x86_64-@VERSION@.run
```

where `@VERSION@` is replaced with the exact driver version.
If you are on ARM, replace Linux-x86_64 with Linux-aarch64.
targets.genericLinux.gpu.nvidia.sha256.type: null or string matching the pattern sha256-.*=

targets.genericLinux.gpu.nvidia.version.description:
The exact version of Nvidia drivers to use. This version **must**
match the version of the driver used by the host OS.
targets.genericLinux.gpu.nvidia.version.type: null or string matching the pattern [0-9]{3}\.[0-9]{2,3}\.[0-9]{2}

targets.genericLinux.gpu.packages.description: The Nixpkgs package set where drivers are taken from.

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.defaultWrappe.description:
The package wrapper function available for use as `(config.lib.nixGL.wrap
<package>)`. Intended to start programs on the main GPU.

Wrapper functions can be found under `config.lib.nixGL.wrappers`. They
can be used directly, however, setting this option provides a convenient
shorthand.

The following wrappers are available:
- mesa
- mesaPrime
- nvidia
- nvidiaPrime

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.installScript.description:
For each wrapper `wrp` named in the provided list, a wrapper script
named `nixGLWrp` is installed into the environment. These scripts are
useful for running programs not installed via Home Manager.

The following wrappers are available:
- mesa
- mesaPrime
- nvidia
- nvidiaPrime

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.offloadWrappe.description:
The package wrapper function available for use as
`(config.lib.nixGL.wrapOffload <package>)`. Intended to start programs
on the secondary GPU.

Wrapper functions can be found under `config.lib.nixGL.wrappers`. They
can be used directly, however, setting this option provides a convenient
shorthand.

The following wrappers are available:
- mesa
- mesaPrime
- nvidia
- nvidiaPrime

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.packages.description:
The nixGL package set containing GPU library wrappers. This can be used
to provide OpenGL and Vulkan access to applications on non-NixOS systems
by using `(config.lib.nixGL.wrap <package>)` for the default wrapper, or
`(config.lib.nixGL.wrappers.<wrapper> <package>)` for any available
wrapper.

The wrapper functions are always available. If this option is empty (the
default), they are a no-op. This is useful on NixOS where the wrappers
are unnecessary.

Note that using any Nvidia wrapper requires building the configuration
with the `--impure` option.

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.prime.card.description:
Selects the non-default graphics card used for PRIME render offloading.
The value can be:

- a number, selecting the n-th non-default GPU;
- a PCI bus id in the form `pci-XXX_YY_ZZ_U`;
- a PCI id in the form `vendor_id:device_id`

For more information, consult the Mesa documentation on the `DRI_PRIME`
environment variable.

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.prime.install.description:
If this option is set, the wrapper script `prime-offload` is installed
into the environment. It allows starting programs on the secondary GPU
selected by the `nixGL.prime.card` option. This makes sense when the
program is not already using one of nixGL PRIME wrappers, or for
programs not installed from Nixpkgs.

This option can be set to either "mesa" or "nvidia", making the script
use one or the other graphics library.

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.prime.nvidiaP.description:
If this option is set, it overrides the offload provider for Nvidia
PRIME offloading. Consult the proprietary Nvidia driver documentation
on the `__NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD_PROVIDER` environment variable.

targets.genericLinux.nixGL.vulkan.enable.description:
Whether to enable Vulkan in nixGL wrappers.

This is disabled by default bacause Vulkan brings in several libraries
that can cause symbol version conflicts in wrapped programs. Your
mileage may vary.

uninstall.description:
Whether to set up a minimal configuration that will remove all managed
files and packages.

Use this with extreme care since running the generated activation script
will remove all Home Manager state from your user environment. This
includes removing all your historic Home Manager generations.

vdirsyncer.authCert.description:
Either a path to a certificate with a client certificate and
the key or a list of paths to the files with them.
vdirsyncer.authCert.type: null or string or list of string

vdirsyncer.clientIdCommand.description:
A command that prints the OAuth credentials to standard
output.

See
<https://vdirsyncer.pimutils.org/en/stable/config.html#google>
for more information.

vdirsyncer.clientSecretCommand.description:
A command that prints the OAuth credentials to standard
output.

See
<https://vdirsyncer.pimutils.org/en/stable/config.html#google>
for more information.

vdirsyncer.collections.description: The collections to synchronize between the storages.
vdirsyncer.collections.type: null or (list of (string or list of string))

vdirsyncer.conflictResolution.description:
What to do in case of a conflict between the storages. Either
`remote wins` or
`local wins` or
a list that contains a command to run. By default, an error
message is printed.
vdirsyncer.conflictResolution.type: null or one of "remote wins", "local wins" or list of string

vdirsyncer.enable.description: Whether to enable synchronization using vdirsyncer.

vdirsyncer.itemTypes.description:
Kinds of items to show. The default is to show everything.
This depends on particular features of the server, the results
are not validated.

vdirsyncer.metadata.description:
Metadata keys that should be synchronized when vdirsyncer
metasync is executed.

vdirsyncer.partialSync.description:
What should happen if synchronization in one direction
is impossible due to one storage being read-only.
Defaults to `revert`.

See
<https://vdirsyncer.pimutils.org/en/stable/config.html#pair-section>
for more information.

vdirsyncer.postHook.description:
Command to call for each item creation and modification.
The command will be called with the path of the new/updated
file.

vdirsyncer.timeRange.description:
A time range to synchronize. start and end can be any Python
expression that returns a `datetime.datetime`
object.

vdirsyncer.timeRange.end.description: End of time range to show.

vdirsyncer.timeRange.start.description: Start of time range to show.

vdirsyncer.tokenFile.description: A file path where access tokens are stored.

vdirsyncer.urlCommand.description: A command that prints the URL of the storage.

vdirsyncer.useVcard4.description:
Specifies whether vdirsyncer should request vCards in version 4.0.
If set to `false` then vdirsyncer will default to version 3.0.

vdirsyncer.userAgent.description:
The user agent to report to the server. Defaults to
`vdirsyncer`.

vdirsyncer.userNameCommand.description: A command that prints the user name to standard output.

vdirsyncer.verify.description: Null or path to certificate to verify SSL against

vdirsyncer.verifyFingerprint.description:
Optional. SHA1 or MD5 fingerprint of the expected server certificate.

See
<https://vdirsyncer.pimutils.org/en/stable/ssl-tutorial.html#ssl-tutorial>
for more information.

wayland.systemd.target.description:
The systemd target that will automatically start the graphical Wayland services.
This option is a generalization of individual `systemd.target` or `systemdTarget`,
and affect all Wayland services by default.

When setting this value to `"sway-session.target"`,
make sure to also enable {option}`wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.enable`,
otherwise the service may never be started.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.enable.description:
Whether to enable configuration for Hyprland, a tiling Wayland
compositor that doesn't sacrifice on its looks.

::: {.note}
This module configures Hyprland and adds it to your user's {env}`PATH`,
but does not make certain system-level changes. NixOS users should
enable the NixOS module with {option}`programs.hyprland.enable`, which
makes system-level changes such as adding a desktop session entry.
:::

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.extraConf.description: Extra configuration lines to add to `~/.config/hypr/hyprland.conf`.

example.text:
''
  # window resize
  bind = $mod, S, submap, resize
  
  submap = resize
  binde = , right, resizeactive, 10 0
  binde = , left, resizeactive, -10 0
  binde = , up, resizeactive, 0 -10
  binde = , down, resizeactive, 0 10
  bind = , escape, submap, reset
  submap = reset
''

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.finalPack.description: The Hyprland package after applying configuration.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.finalPort.description: The xdg-desktop-portal-hyprland package after overriding its hyprland input.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.important.description: List of prefix of attributes to source at the top of the config.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.package.description: The hyprland package to use. Set this to null if you use the NixOS module to install Hyprland.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.plugins.description:
List of Hyprland plugins to use. Can either be packages or
absolute plugin paths.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.settings.description:
Hyprland configuration written in Nix. Entries with the same key
should be written as lists. Variables' and colors' names should be
quoted. See <https://wiki.hypr.land> for more examples.

::: {.note}
Use the [](#opt-wayland.windowManager.hyprland.plugins) option to
declare plugins.
:::

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.sourceFir.description:
Whether to enable putting source entries at the top of the configuration
.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.submaps.description:
Attribute set of Hyprland submaps.

See <https://wiki.hypr.land/Configuring/Binds#submaps> to learn about submaps

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.submaps.<.description: Hyprland binds to be put in the submap

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.systemd.e.description:
Whether to enable {file}`hyprland-session.target` on
hyprland startup. This links to `graphical-session.target`.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and D-Bus user environment before reaching the target, including
- `DISPLAY`
- `HYPRLAND_INSTANCE_SIGNATURE`
- `WAYLAND_DISPLAY`
- `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`
- `XDG_SESSION_TYPE`

Whether to enable autostart of applications using
{manpage}`systemd-xdg-autostart-generator(8)`.
Extra commands to be run after D-Bus activation.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.systemd.v.description:
Environment variables to be imported in the systemd & D-Bus user
environment.

wayland.windowManager.hyprland.xwayland..description:
Whether or not to enable XWayland.

Overrides the `enableXWayland` option of the Hyprland package.

In newer versions of Hyprland, you can use the {option}`wayland.windowManager.hyprland.settings.xwayland`
option to avoid recompiling Hyprland.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.autostart.description: Command to autostart when labwc start.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.enable.description: Whether to enable Labwc, a wayland window-stacking compositor.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.environment.description: Environment variable to add when labwc start.

example.text:
''
  <tablet mapToOutput="" rotate="0" mouseEmulation="no">
    <!-- Active area dimensions are in mm -->
    <area top="0.0" left="0.0" width="0.0" height="0.0" />
    <map button="Tip" to="Left" />
    <map button="Stylus" to="Right" />
    <map button="Stylus2" to="Middle" />
  </tablet>
''

wayland.windowManager.labwc.package.description: The labwc package to use. Set to `null` to use Nixos labwc package.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.rc.description:
Config to configure labwc options.
Use "@attributes" for attributes.
See <https://labwc.github.io/labwc-config.5.html> for configuration.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.systemd.enab.description:
Whether to enable {file}`labwc-session.target` on
labwc startup. This links to {file}`graphical-session.target`.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and D-Bus user environment before reaching the target, including
- `DISPLAY`
- `WAYLAND_DISPLAY`
- `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`

wayland.windowManager.labwc.systemd.extr.description: Extra commands to be run after D-Bus activation.

wayland.windowManager.labwc.systemd.vari.description:
Environment variables to be imported in the systemd & D-Bus user
environment.

wayland.windowManager.river.enable.description: Whether to enable the river window manager.

wayland.windowManager.river.extraSession.description: Extra session variables set when running the compositor.

wayland.windowManager.river.package.description:
The river-classic package to use. Set to `null` to not add any river package to your path.
This should be done if you want to use the NixOS river module to install river.

wayland.windowManager.river.systemd.enab.description:
Whether to enable {file}`river-session.target` on
river startup. This links to {file}`graphical-session.target`}.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and D-Bus user environment before reaching the target, including
- `DISPLAY`
- `WAYLAND_DISPLAY`
- `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`
- `NIXOS_OZONE_WL`
- `XCURSOR_THEME`
- `XCURSOR_SIZE`

wayland.windowManager.river.systemd.extr.description: Extra commands to be run after D-Bus activation.

wayland.windowManager.river.systemd.vari.description:
Environment variables to be imported in the systemd & D-Bus user
environment.

wayland.windowManager.sway.checkConfig.description: If enabled, validates the generated config file.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.assign.description:
An attribute set that assigns applications to workspaces based
on criteria.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.assign.type: attribute set of list of attribute set of (string or boolean)

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.description: Sway bars settings blocks. Set to empty list to remove bars completely.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description:
Bar color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', fields and RGB color hex-codes as values.
See default values for the reference.
Note that 'background', 'status', and 'separator' parameters take a single RGB value.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_colors>.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace is active.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Background color of the bar.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Border, background and text color for the binding mode indicator
Background color of the bar on the currently focused monitor output.
Text color to be used for the separator on the currently focused monitor output.
Text color to be used for the statusline on the currently focused monitor output.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace has focus.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description:
Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace does not
have focus and is not active.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Text color to be used for the separator.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Text color to be used for the statusline.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description:
Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace contains
a window with the urgency hint set.
Command that will be used to start a bar.
Extra configuration lines for this bar.
Font configuration for this bar.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: The default bar mode when 'bar.mode' == 'hide'.

Specifies the bar ID for the configured bar instance.
If this option is missing, the ID is set to bar-x, where x corresponds
to the position of the embedding bar block in the config file.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Bar visibility mode.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: The edge of the screen swaybar should show up.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Command that will be used to get status lines.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Where to output tray.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description:
Sets the pixel padding of the system tray.
This padding will surround the tray on all sides and between each item.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Whether workspace buttons should be shown or not.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bars.*.description: Whether workspace numbers should be displayed within the workspace buttons.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bindke.description: Whether to make use of {option}`--to-code` in keybindings.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.bindsw.description:
Binds <switch> to execute the sway command command on state changes. Supported switches are lid (laptop
lid) and tablet (tablet mode) switches. Valid values for state are on, off and toggle. These switches are
on when the device lid is shut and when tablet mode is active respectively. toggle is also supported to run
a command both when the switch is toggled on or off.
See sway(5).
The sway command to execute on state changes

Unless the flag --locked is set, the command
will not be run when a screen locking program
is active. If there is a matching binding with
and without --locked, the one with will be preferred
when locked and the one without will be
preferred when unlocked.

If the --reload flag is given, the binding will
also be executed when the config is reloaded.
toggle bindings will not be executed on reload.
The --locked flag will operate as normal so if
the config is reloaded while locked and
--locked is not given, the binding will not be
executed.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.colors.description:
Color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', 'indicator' and 'childBorder' fields
and RGB color hex-codes as values. See default values for the reference.
Note that 'sway.config.colors.background' parameter takes a single RGB value.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_changing_colors>.

Background color of the window. Only applications which do not cover
the whole area expose the color.
A window which currently has the focus.

A window which is the focused one of its container,
but it does not have the focus at the moment.

Background and text color are used to draw placeholder window
contents (when restoring layouts). Border and indicator are ignored.
A window which is not focused.
A window which has its urgency hint activated.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.defaul.description:
The default workspace to show when sway is launched.
This must to correspond to the value of the keybinding of the default workspace.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.down.description: Home row direction key for moving down.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.floati.description: List of criteria for windows that should be opened in a floating mode.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.floati.type: list of attribute set of (string or boolean)

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.floati.description: Modifier key or keys that can be used to drag floating windows.

default.text:
''
  true for state version ≥ 23.05
  false for state version < 23.05
''

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.floati.description: Whether to show floating window titlebars.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.focus..description: Whether focus should follow the mouse.

Whether to force focus wrapping in tabbed or stacked containers.

This option is deprecated, use {option}`focus.wrapping` instead.

Whether mouse cursor should be warped to the center of the window when switching focus
to a window on a different output.

This option modifies focus behavior on new window activation.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#focus_on_window_activation>

Whether the window focus commands automatically wrap around the edge of containers.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_focus_wrapping>

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.fonts.description: Font configuration for window titles, nagbar...

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.gaps.s.description:
This option controls whether to disable container borders on
workspace with a single container.

This option controls whether to disable all gaps (outer and inner)
on workspace with a single container.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.input.description:
An attribute set that defines input modules. See
{manpage}`sway-input(5)`
for options.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.input.type: attribute set of attribute set of string

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.keybin.description:
An attribute set that assigns a key press to an action using a key symbol.
See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#keybindings>.

Consider to use `lib.mkOptionDefault` function to extend or override
default keybindings instead of specifying all of them from scratch.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.keycod.description:
An attribute set that assigns keypress to an action using key code.
See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#keybindings>.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.left.description: Home row direction key for moving left.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.modes.description:
An attribute set that defines binding modes and keybindings
inside them

Only basic keybinding is supported (bindsym keycomb action),
for more advanced setup use 'sway.extraConfig'.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.modes.type: attribute set of attribute set of string

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.modifi.description: Modifier key that is used for all default keybindings.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.output.description:
An attribute set that defines output modules. See
{manpage}`sway-output(5)`
for options.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.output.type: attribute set of attribute set of string

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.right.description: Home row direction key for moving right.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.seat.description:
An attribute set that defines seat modules. See
{manpage}`sway-input(5)`
for options.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.seat.type: attribute set of attribute set of string

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.startu.description:
Commands that should be executed at startup.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_automatically_starting_applications_on_i3_startup>.
Whether to run command on each sway restart.
Command that will be executed on startup.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.up.description: Home row direction key for moving up.

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.description:
List of commands that should be executed on specific windows.
See {option}`for_window` swaywm option documentation.

Criteria of the windows on which command should be executed.

A value of `true` is equivalent to using an empty
criteria (which is different from an empty string criteria).
Hide window borders adjacent to the screen edges.
wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.type: one of "none", "vertical", "horizontal", "both", "smart", "smart_no_gaps", "--i3 none", "--i3 vertical", "--i3 horizontal", "--i3 both", "--i3 smart", "--i3 smart_no_gaps"

default.text:
''
  true for state version ≥ 23.05
  false for state version < 23.05
''

wayland.windowManager.sway.config.worksp.description:
Assume you are on workspace "1: www" and switch to "2: IM" using
mod+2 because somebody sent you a message. You don’t need to remember
where you came from now, you can just press $mod+2 again to switch
back to "1: www".

The mode in which new containers on workspace level will
start.

Name(s) of the output(s) from {command}`
  swaymsg -t get_outputs
`.
Name of the workspace to assign.

wayland.windowManager.sway.enable.description: Whether to enable sway wayland compositor.

wayland.windowManager.sway.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration lines to add to ~/.config/sway/config.

wayland.windowManager.sway.extraConfigEa.description: Like extraConfig, except lines are added to ~/.config/sway/config before all other configuration.

wayland.windowManager.sway.extraOptions.description:
Command line arguments passed to launch Sway. Please DO NOT report
issues if you use an unsupported GPU (proprietary drivers).

wayland.windowManager.sway.extraSessionC.description: Shell commands executed just before Sway is started.

example.text:
''
  export SDL_VIDEODRIVER=wayland
  # needs qt5.qtwayland in systemPackages
  export QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland
  export QT_WAYLAND_DISABLE_WINDOWDECORATION="1"
  # Fix for some Java AWT applications (e.g. Android Studio),
  # use this if they aren't displayed properly:
  export _JAVA_AWT_WM_NONREPARENTING=1
''

wayland.windowManager.sway.package.description:
Sway package to use. Will override the options
'wrapperFeatures', 'extraSessionCommands', and 'extraOptions'.
Set to `null` to not add any Sway package to your
path. This should be done if you want to use the NixOS Sway
module to install Sway. Beware setting to `null` will also disable
reloading Sway when new config is activated.

wayland.windowManager.sway.swaynag.enabl.description: Whether to enable configuration of swaynag, a lightweight error bar for sway.

wayland.windowManager.sway.swaynag.setti.description:
Configuration written to
{file}`$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/swaynag/config`.

See
{manpage}`swaynag(5)`
for a list of available options and an example configuration.
Note, configurations declared under `<config>`
will override the default type values of swaynag.
wayland.windowManager.sway.swaynag.setti.type: attribute set of attribute set of (Swaynag config atom (null, bool, int, float, str))

wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.dbusI.description:
The D-Bus implementation used on the system.
This affects which tool is used to import environment variables when starting the Sway session.
On NixOS, this should match the value of the option [`services.dbus.implementation` (NixOS)](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/stable/options#opt-services.dbus.implementation).
When set to `dbus`, `dbus-update-activation-environment --systemd <variables>` is run.
Otherwise, when set to `broker`, `systemctl --user import-environment <variables>` is run.
See <https://github.com/swaywm/sway/wiki#systemd-and-dbus-activation-environments> for more documentation.

wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.enabl.description:
Whether to enable {file}`sway-session.target` on
sway startup. This links to
{file}`graphical-session.target`.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and dbus user environment before reaching the target, including
* {env}`DISPLAY`
* {env}`WAYLAND_DISPLAY`
* {env}`SWAYSOCK`
* {env}`XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`
* {env}`XDG_SESSION_TYPE`
* {env}`NIXOS_OZONE_WL`
* {env}`XCURSOR_THEME`
* {env}`XCURSOR_SIZE`
You can extend this list using the `systemd.variables` option.

default.text:
[
  "systemctl --user reset-failed"
  "systemctl --user start sway-session.target"
  "swaymsg -mt subscribe '[]' || true"
  "systemctl --user stop sway-session.target"
]

wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.extra.description: Extra commands to run after D-Bus activation.

wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.varia.description: Environment variables imported into the systemd and D-Bus user environment.

wayland.windowManager.sway.systemd.xdgAu.description:
Whether to enable autostart of applications using
{manpage}`systemd-xdg-autostart-generator(8)`
.

wayland.windowManager.sway.wrapperFeatur.description: Attribute set of features to enable in the wrapper.

Whether to make use of the base wrapper to execute extra session commands and prepend a
dbus-run-session to the sway command.

Whether to make use of the wrapGAppsHook wrapper to execute sway with required environment
variables for GTK applications.

wayland.windowManager.sway.xwayland.description: Enable xwayland, which is needed for the default configuration of sway.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.enable.description: Whether to enable Wayfire, a wayland compositor based on wlroots.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.package.description:
The wayfire package to use. Set to `null` to not add any wayfire package to your path.
This should be done if you want to use the NixOS wayfire module to install wayfire.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.plugins.description: Additional plugins to use with wayfire

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.settings.description:
Wayfire configuration written in Nix.

See <https://github.com/WayfireWM/wayfire/wiki/Configuration>
wayland.windowManager.wayfire.settings.type: open submodule of attribute set of attribute set of (string or absolute path or boolean or signed integer or floating point number)

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.systemd.en.description:
Whether to enable {file}`wayfire-session.target` on
wayfire startup. This links to {file}`graphical-session.target`}.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and D-Bus user environment before reaching the target, including
- `DISPLAY`
- `WAYLAND_DISPLAY`
- `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`
- `NIXOS_OZONE_WL`

- `XCURSOR_SIZE`

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.systemd.ex.description: Extra commands to be run after D-Bus activation.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.systemd.va.description:
Environment variables to be imported in the systemd & D-Bus user
environment.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.wf-shell.e.description: Whether to enable Manage wf-shell Configuration.

wayland.windowManager.wayfire.wf-shell.s.description:
Wf-shell configuration written in Nix.

See <https://github.com/WayfireWM/wf-shell/blob/master/wf-shell.ini.example>
wayland.windowManager.wayfire.wf-shell.s.type: attribute set of attribute set of (string or absolute path or boolean or signed integer or floating point number)

xdg.autostart.enable.description: Whether to enable creation of XDG autostart entries.

xdg.autostart.entries.description: Paths to desktop files that should be linked to `XDG_CONFIG_HOME/autostart`

xdg.autostart.readOnly.description:
Make `XDG_CONFIG_HOME/autostart` a symlink to a readonly directory so that
programs cannot install arbitrary autostart services.

xdg.cacheFile.description:
Attribute set of files to link into the user's XDG
cache home.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.enable.description:
Whether this file should be generated. This option allows specific
files to be disabled.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.executable.description:
Set the execute bit. If `null`, defaults to the mode
of the {var}`source` file or to `false`
for files created through the {var}`text` option.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.force.description:
Whether the target path should be unconditionally replaced
by the managed file source. Warning, this will silently
delete the target regardless of whether it is a file or
link.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.ignorelinks.description:
When `recursive` is enabled, adds `-ignorelinks` flag to lndir

It causes lndir to not treat symbolic links in the source directory specially.
The link created in the target directory will point back to the corresponding
(symbolic link) file in the source directory. If the link is to a directory

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.onChange.description:
Shell commands to run when file has changed between
generations. The script will be run
*after* the new files have been linked
into place.

Note, this code is always run when `recursive` is
enabled.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.recursive.description:
If the file source is a directory, then this option
determines whether the directory should be recursively
linked to the target location. This option has no effect
if the source is a file.

If `false` (the default) then the target
will be a symbolic link to the source directory. If
`true` then the target will be a
directory structure matching the source's but whose leafs
are symbolic links to the files of the source directory.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.source.description:
Path of the source file or directory. If
[](#opt-xdg.cacheFile._name_.text)
is non-null then this option will automatically point to a file
containing that text.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.target.description: Path to target file relative to {var}`xdg.cacheHome`.

xdg.cacheFile.<name>.text.description:
Text of the file. If this option is null then
[](#opt-xdg.cacheFile._name_.source)
must be set.

xdg.cacheHome.description:
Absolute path to directory holding application caches.

Sets `XDG_CACHE_HOME` for the user if `xdg.enable` is set `true`.

Attribute set of files to link into the user's XDG

Absolute path to directory holding application data.

Sets `XDG_DATA_HOME` for the user if `xdg.enable` is set `true`.

xdg.desktopEntries.description:
Desktop Entries allow applications to be shown in your desktop environment's app launcher.

You can define entries for programs without entries or override existing entries.

See <https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/recognized-keys.html> for more information on options.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.actions.description: The set of actions made available to application launchers.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.actions.<name>.description: Program to execute, possibly with arguments.
Icon to display in file manager, menus, etc.
xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.actions.<name>.type: null or string or absolute path

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.categories.description: Categories in which the entry should be shown in a menu.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.exec.description: Program to execute, possibly with arguments.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.icon.description: Icon to display in file manager, menus, etc.
xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.icon.type: null or string or absolute path

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.mimeType.description: The MIME type(s) supported by this application.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.noDisplay.description:
Means "this application exists, but don't display it in the menus".
This can be useful to e.g. associate this application with MIME types.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.prefersNonDefa.description: If true, the application prefers to be run on a more powerful discrete GPU if available.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.settings.description:
Extra key-value pairs to add to the `[Desktop Entry]` section.
This may override other values.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.startupNotify.description:
If true, it is KNOWN that the application will send a "remove"
message when started with the `DESKTOP_STARTUP_ID`
environment variable set. If false, it is KNOWN that the application
does not work with startup notification at all.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.terminal.description: Whether the program runs in a terminal window.

xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.type.description: The type of the desktop entry.

xdg.enable.description: Whether to enable management of XDG base directories.

xdg.mime.desktopFileUtilsPackage.description: The desktop-file-utils package to use. Used when running update-desktop-database.

default.text: true if host platform is Linux, false otherwise

xdg.mime.enable.description:
Whether to install programs and files to support the
XDG Shared MIME-info specification and XDG MIME Applications
specification at
<https://specifications.freedesktop.org/shared-mime-info-spec/shared-mime-info-spec-latest.html>
and
<https://specifications.freedesktop.org/mime-apps-spec/mime-apps-spec-latest.html>,
respectively.

xdg.mime.sharedMimeInfoPackage.description: The shared-mime-info package to use. Used when running update-mime-database.

xdg.mimeApps.associations.added.description:
Defines additional associations of applications with
mimetypes, as if the .desktop file was listing this mimetype
in the first place.
xdg.mimeApps.associations.added.type: attribute set of ((list of string) or ((list of string) or string) convertible to it)

xdg.mimeApps.associations.removed.description:
Removes associations of applications with mimetypes, as if the
.desktop file was *not* listing this
mimetype in the first place.
xdg.mimeApps.associations.removed.type: attribute set of ((list of string) or ((list of string) or string) convertible to it)

xdg.mimeApps.defaultApplicationPackages.description:
Packages whose `.desktop` files will be used to establish default
mimetype associations.

These associations are appended to the associations in
[](#opt-xdg.mimeApps.defaultApplications). If multiple packages
associate with the same mime type, then the priority among them is
determined by their order in the list.

xdg.mimeApps.defaultApplications.description:
The default application to be used for a given mimetype. This
is, for instance, the one that will be started when
double-clicking on a file in a file manager. If the
application is no longer installed, the next application in
the list is attempted, and so on.
xdg.mimeApps.defaultApplications.type: attribute set of ((list of string) or ((list of string) or string) convertible to it)

xdg.mimeApps.enable.description:
Whether to manage {file}`$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/mimeapps.list`.

The generated file is read-only.

xdg.portal.config.description:
Sets which portal backend should be used to provide the implementation
for the requested interface. For details check {manpage}`portals.conf(5)`.

These will be written with the name `$desktop-portals.conf` for
`xdg.portal.config.$desktop` and `portals.conf` for
`xdg.portal.config.common` as an exception.

These, together with `xdg.portal.configPackages`, will be joined into a
directory and passed to `xdg-desktop-portal.service` through a
`NIXOS_XDG_DESKTOP_PORTAL_CONFIG_DIR` variable.
xdg.portal.config.type: attribute set of attribute set of (string or ((list of string) or string) convertible to it)

xdg.portal.configPackages.description:
List of packages that provide XDG desktop portal configuration, usually in
the form of `share/xdg-desktop-portal/$desktop-portals.conf`.

Note that configs in `xdg.portal.config` will be preferred if set.

xdg.portal.enable.description:
Whether to enable [XDG desktop integration](https://github.com/flatpak/xdg-desktop-portal).

Note, if you installed Home Manager via its NixOS module and
'home-manager.useUserPackages' is enabled, make sure to add

``` nix
environment.pathsToLink = [ "/share/xdg-desktop-portal" "/share/applications" ];
```

to your NixOS configuration so that the portal definitions and DE
provided configurations get linked.

xdg.portal.extraPortals.description:
List of additional portals that should be added to the environment.

The directory where the portal definitions have been merged together
(likely `~/.nix-profile/share/xdg-desktop-portal/portals`) will get
passed to `xdg-desktop-portal.service` via the
`NIX_XDG_DESKTOP_PORTAL_DIR` environment variable.

Portals allow interaction with system, like choosing files or taking
screenshots. At minimum, a desktop portal implementation should be
listed.

xdg.portal.xdgOpenUsePortal.description:
Sets environment variable `NIXOS_XDG_OPEN_USE_PORTAL` to `1`
This will make `xdg-open` use the portal to open programs, which resolves bugs involving
programs opening inside FHS envs or with unexpected env vars set from wrappers.
See [#160923](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/issues/160923) for more info.

xdg.stateFile.<name>.recursive.description:
If the file source is a directory, then this option
determines whether the directory should be recursively
linked to the target location. This option has no effect
if the source is a file.

If `false` (the default) then the target
will be a symbolic link to the source directory. If
`true` then the target will be a
directory structure matching the source's but whose leafs
are symbolic links to the files of the source directory.

xdg.stateFile.<name>.source.description:
Path of the source file or directory. If
[](#opt-xdg.stateFile._name_.text)
is non-null then this option will automatically point to a file
containing that text.

xdg.stateFile.<name>.target.description: Path to target file relative to <varname>xdg.stateHome</varname>.

xdg.stateFile.<name>.text.description:
Text of the file. If this option is null then
[](#opt-xdg.stateFile._name_.source)
must be set.

xdg.stateHome.description:
Absolute path to directory holding application states.

Sets `XDG_STATE_HOME` for the user if `xdg.enable` is set `true`.

xdg.systemDirs.config.description:
Directory names to add to {env}`XDG_CONFIG_DIRS`
in the user session.

xdg.systemDirs.data.description:
Directory names to add to {env}`XDG_DATA_DIRS`
in the user session.

xdg.terminal-exec.enable.description:
Whether to enable xdg-terminal-exec, the
[proposed](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xdg/xdg-specs/-/merge_requests/46)
Default Terminal Execution Specification.

xdg.terminal-exec.settings.description:
Configuration options for the Default Terminal Execution Specification.

The keys are the desktop environments that are matched (case-insensitively) against {env}`XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP`,
or `default` which is used when the current desktop environment is not found in the configuration.
The values are a list of terminals' [desktop file IDs](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s02.html#desktop-file-id) to try in order of decreasing priority.
xdg.terminal-exec.settings.type: attribute set of list of string

xdg.userDirs.createDirectories.description: Whether to enable automatic creation of the XDG user directories.

xdg.userDirs.desktop.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.documents.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.download.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.enable.description:
Whether to manage {file}`$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/user-dirs.dirs`.

The generated file is read-only.

xdg.userDirs.extraConfig.type: attribute set of (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.music.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.pictures.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.publicShare.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.templates.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xdg.userDirs.videos.type: null or (string or absolute path convertible to it)

xfconf.settings.description: Settings to write to the Xfconf configuration system.

xresources.extraConfig.description:
Additional X server resources contents.
If this and all other xresources options are
`null`, then this feature is disabled and no
{file}`~/.Xresources` link is produced.

xresources.path.description: Path where Home Manager should link the {file}`.Xresources` file.

xresources.properties.description:
X server resources that should be set.
Booleans are formatted as "true" or "false" respectively.
List elements are recursively formatted as a string and joined by commas.
All other values are directly formatted using builtins.toString.
Note, that 2-dimensional lists are not supported and specifying one will throw an exception.
If this and all other xresources options are
`null`, then this feature is disabled and no
{file}`~/.Xresources` link is produced.
xresources.properties.type: null or (attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or floating point number or string or list of (boolean or signed integer or floating point number or string)))

xsession.initExtra.description: Extra shell commands to run during initialization.

xsession.preferStatusNotifierItems.description:
Whether tray applets should prefer using the Status Notifier
Items (SNI) protocol, commonly called App Indicators. Note,
not all tray applets or status bars support SNI.

xsession.profileExtra.description: Extra shell commands to run before session start.

xsession.profilePath.description:
Path, relative to {env}`HOME`, where Home Manager
should write the X profile script.

xsession.scriptPath.description:
Path, relative to {env}`HOME`, where Home Manager
should write the X session script.

xsession.windowManager.awesome.enable.description: Whether to enable Awesome window manager.

xsession.windowManager.awesome.luaModule.description:
List of lua packages available for being
used in the Awesome configuration.

xsession.windowManager.awesome.noArgb.description:
Disable client transparency support, which can be greatly
detrimental to performance in some setups

xsession.windowManager.awesome.package.description: The awesome package to use. to use for running the Awesome WM

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.alwaysReset.description:
If set to `true`, desktops configured in {option}`monitors` will be reset
every time the config is run.

If set to `false`, desktops will only be configured the first time the config is run.
This is useful if you want to dynamically add desktops and you don't want them to be destroyed if you
re-run `bspwmrc`.

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.enable.description: Whether to enable bspwm window manager.

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.extraConfig.description: Additional shell commands to be run at the end of the config file.
Like extraConfig, except commands are run at the start of the config file.

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.monitors.description: Specifies the names of desktops to create on each monitor.
xsession.windowManager.bspwm.monitors.type: attribute set of list of string

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.rules.description: Rule configuration. The keys of the attribute set are the targets of the rules.
xsession.windowManager.bspwm.rules.type: attribute set of (open submodule of attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or floating point number or string))

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.rules.<name.description: Whether the node should have border.
Whether the node will be put in the center, in floating mode.
The desktop where the rule should be applied.
Whether the node should gain focus on creation.
Whether focus should follow the node when it is moved.
Whether the node should occupy any space.
The layer where a new window should spawn.

Whether the node should ignore {command}`node --close`
messages.

Whether the window should be managed by bspwm. If false, the window
will be ignored by bspwm entirely. This is useful for overlay apps,
e.g. screenshot tools.
Whether the node will be marked for deferred actions.
The monitor where the rule should be applied.
The node where the rule should be applied.
Whether the node should stay in the same tiling position and size.
The node's geometry, in the format `WxH+X+Y`.
The direction where the container is going to be split.

The ratio between the new window and the previous existing window in
the desktop.
The state in which a new window should spawn.
Whether the node should stay on the focused desktop.

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.settings.type: attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or floating point number or string or list of (boolean or signed integer or floating point number or string))

xsession.windowManager.bspwm.startupProg.description: Programs to be executed during startup.

xsession.windowManager.command.description:
Command to use to start the window manager.

The default value allows integration with NixOS' generated xserver configuration.

Extra actions and commands can be specified in {option}`xsession.initExtra`.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.apps.description:
Apps configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/apps`. Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.enable.description: Whether to enable Fluxbox window manager.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.extraComm.description:
Extra command line arguments to pass to {command}`fluxbox`.
Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.init.description:
Init configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/init`. Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.keys.description:
Keyboard shortcuts configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/keys`. Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox-keys(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.menu.description:
Menu configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/menu`. Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox-menu(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.slitlist.description:
Slitlist configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/slitlist`. Look at the
{manpage}`fluxbox(1)` manpage for details.

xsession.windowManager.fluxbox.windowmen.description:
Window menu configuration for Fluxbox, written to
{file}`~/.fluxbox/windowmenu`. Look at the

xsession.windowManager.herbstluftwm.enab.description: Whether to enable herbstluftwm window manager.

Set an alias for the {command}`herbstclient` command in the
{file}`autostart` script that only stores its arguments and executes
them all at once at the end of the {file}`autostart` script.

This reduces the amount of flickering you get while all options are
being applied and improves the performance.

On the other hand, this makes it more difficult to write bash functions
that call {command}`herbstclient`. You can work around this by calling
{command}`command herbstclient` in your functions to still get some of
the benefits of enabling this alias.

xsession.windowManager.herbstluftwm.extr.description:
Extra configuration lines to add verbatim to
{file}`$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/herbstluftwm/autostart`.

xsession.windowManager.herbstluftwm.sett.type: attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or string)

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.assigns.description:
An attribute set that assigns applications to workspaces based
on criteria.
xsession.windowManager.i3.config.assigns.type: attribute set of list of attribute set of (string or boolean)

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.description: i3 bars settings blocks. Set to empty list to remove bars completely.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description:
Bar color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', fields and RGB color hex-codes as values.
See default values for the reference.
Note that 'background', 'status', and 'separator' parameters take a single RGB value.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_colors>.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace is active.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Background color of the bar.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Border, background and text color for the binding mode indicator
Background color of the bar on the currently focused monitor output.
Text color to be used for the separator on the currently focused monitor output.
Text color to be used for the statusline on the currently focused monitor output.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace has focus.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description:
Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace does not
have focus and is not active.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Text color to be used for the separator.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Text color to be used for the statusline.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description:
Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace contains
a window with the urgency hint set.
Command that will be used to start a bar.
Extra configuration lines for this bar.
Font configuration for this bar.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: The default bar mode when 'bar.mode' == 'hide'.

Specifies the bar ID for the configured bar instance.
If this option is missing, the ID is set to bar-x, where x corresponds
to the position of the embedding bar block in the config file.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Bar visibility mode.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: The edge of the screen i3bar should show up.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Command that will be used to get status lines.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Where to output tray.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description:
Sets the pixel padding of the system tray.
This padding will surround the tray on all sides and between each item.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Whether workspace buttons should be shown or not.

default.text: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*..description: Whether workspace numbers should be displayed within the workspace buttons.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.description:
Color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', 'indicator' and 'childBorder' fields
and RGB color hex-codes as values. See default values for the reference.
Note that 'i3.config.colors.background' parameter takes a single RGB value.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_changing_colors>.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors..description:
Background color of the window. Only applications which do not cover
the whole area expose the color.
A window which currently has the focus.

A window which is the focused one of its container,
but it does not have the focus at the moment.

Background and text color are used to draw placeholder window
contents (when restoring layouts). Border and indicator are ignored.
A window which is not focused.
A window which has its urgency hint activated.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.default.description:
The default workspace to show when i3 is launched.
This must to correspond to the value of the keybinding of the default workspace.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.floatin.description: List of criteria for windows that should be opened in a floating mode.
xsession.windowManager.i3.config.floatin.type: list of attribute set of (string or boolean)

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.floatin.description: Modifier key or keys that can be used to drag floating windows.

default.text:
''
  true for state version ≥ 23.05
  config.gaps == null for state version < 23.05
''

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.floatin.description: Whether to show floating window titlebars.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.focus.f.description: Whether focus should follow the mouse.

Whether to force focus wrapping in tabbed or stacked containers.

This option is deprecated, use {option}`focus.wrapping` instead.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.focus.m.description:
Whether mouse cursor should be warped to the center of the window when switching focus
to a window on a different output.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.focus.n.description:
This option modifies focus behavior on new window activation.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#focus_on_window_activation>

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.focus.w.description:
Whether the window focus commands automatically wrap around the edge of containers.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_focus_wrapping>

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.fonts.description: Font configuration for window titles, nagbar...

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.gaps.sm.description:
This option controls whether to disable container borders on
workspace with a single container.

This option controls whether to disable all gaps (outer and inner)
on workspace with a single container.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.keybind.description:
An attribute set that assigns a key press to an action using a key symbol.
See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#keybindings>.

Consider to use `lib.mkOptionDefault` function to extend or override
default keybindings instead of specifying all of them from scratch.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.keycode.description:
An attribute set that assigns keypress to an action using key code.
See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#keybindings>.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.modes.description:
An attribute set that defines binding modes and keybindings
inside them

Only basic keybinding is supported (bindsym keycomb action),
for more advanced setup use 'i3.extraConfig'.
xsession.windowManager.i3.config.modes.type: attribute set of attribute set of string

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.modifie.description: Modifier key that is used for all default keybindings.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.startup.description:
Commands that should be executed at startup.

See <https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_automatically_starting_applications_on_i3_startup>.
Whether to run command on each i3 restart.
Command that will be executed on startup.

Whether to enable startup-notification support for the command.
See {option}`--no-startup-id` option description in the i3 user guide.

Launch application on a particular workspace. DEPRECATED:
Use [](#opt-xsession.windowManager.i3.config.assigns)
instead. See <https://github.com/nix-community/home-manager/issues/265>.

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.window..description:
List of commands that should be executed on specific windows.
See {option}`for_window` i3wm option documentation.

Criteria of the windows on which command should be executed.

A value of `true` is equivalent to using an empty
criteria (which is different from an empty string criteria).
Hide window borders adjacent to the screen edges.

default.text:
''
  true for state version ≥ 23.05
  config.gaps == null for state version < 23.05
''

xsession.windowManager.i3.config.workspa.description:
Assume you are on workspace "1: www" and switch to "2: IM" using
mod+2 because somebody sent you a message. You don’t need to remember
where you came from now, you can just press $mod+2 again to switch
back to "1: www".

The mode in which new containers on workspace level will
start.

Name(s) of the output(s) from {command}`
  i3-msg -t get_outputs
`.
Name of the workspace to assign.

xsession.windowManager.i3.enable.description: Whether to enable i3 window manager.

xsession.windowManager.i3.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration lines to add to ~/.config/i3/config.

xsession.windowManager.spectrwm.enable.description: Whether to enable Spectrwm window manager.

xsession.windowManager.spectrwm.package.description: The spectrwm package to use. providing the spectrwm command

xsession.windowManager.spectrwm.settings.type: attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or string)

xsession.windowManager.spectrwm.unbindin.description: List of keybindings to disable from default Spectrwm configuration.

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.buildScrip.description: Build script for your xmonad configuration.

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.config.description:
The configuration file to be used for xmonad. This must be
an absolute path or `null` in which case
{file}`~/.xmonad/xmonad.hs` will not be managed
by Home Manager.

If this option is set to a non-`null` value,
recompilation of xmonad outside of Home Manager (e.g. via
{command}`xmonad --recompile`) will fail.

example.text:
pkgs.writeText "xmonad.hs" ''
  import XMonad
  main = xmonad defaultConfig
      { terminal    = "urxvt"
      , modMask     = mod4Mask
      , borderWidth = 3
      }
''

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.enable.description: Whether to enable xmonad window manager.

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.extraPacka.description:
Extra packages available to GHC when rebuilding xmonad. The
value must be a function which receives the attribute set
defined in {var}`haskellPackages` as the sole
argument.

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.haskellPac.description:
The {var}`haskellPackages` used to build xmonad
and other packages. This can be used to change the GHC
version used to build xmonad and the packages listed in
{var}`extraPackages`.

xsession.windowManager.xmonad.libFiles.description:
Additional files that will be saved in
{file}`~/.xmonad/lib/` and included in the configuration
build. The keys are the file names while the values are paths to the
contents of the files.
